content.description: fun slab with a ton of features!
content.protection: 3 bolts, no top anchors walk off.
content.location: It’s the slab on the left side of the dihedral in the middle of the wall. You can’t really miss the bolts.

content.description: Prominent left facing dihedral in the center of the wall. Climb short slab to crack and follow corner to the top. The crack is flaring and isn’t much a fan of cams.
content.protection: Large passive pro, hexes ect. Walk off climbers left.
content.location: 25’ left of codger is a dihedral. This is off your rocker! It’s about dead center of the riven wall.

content.description: There’s no distinct crux, the new leader may find getting established in the crack to be a challenge. Hand/fist crack that ends near top. Finish on face to top.
content.protection: Few cams from .5 - 3 and some nuts. Sling the finger like boulder or build gear anchor.
content.location: 25’ of the left facing dihedral (off your rocker). Obvious hand/fist crack.

content.description: The arete on the left hand side of the alcove with codgers. Walk around back and sling finger like boulder. You can stand on the boulder and stare down the arete after you set up the TR.
content.location: The arete maybe 10’ left of codger.

climbs.name: Bees Knees
climbs.fa: Michael Genovese, Tyler Collins, Amber Asay

content.description: Delicate feet and friction will find your way past the first bolt. Sharp edges and a few perfectly placed quartz crystals will see you the rest of the way to the top.
content.location: Climbers right of Off your rocker and Bee yourself.

content.description: Climb slab start same as off your rocker to initially thin crack which opens to hands then to OW. I bumped a #4 up the last 10 feet, a #5 would protect the very easy top out. There is no pro until you get to the crack, but it's fairly straight forward 5.easy slab.
content.protection: Light rack and offset nuts (FA used blue DMM offset, .3, 1, 4). A #4 is needed for the top, #5 is optional. No fixed anchor, can be TR'd with the anchors to the right and a directional in the crack.
content.location: Same start as off your rocker. Instead of climbing the dihedral head straight up.

content.description: North facing wall with afternoon shade. Easily identified by its broken face. There’s no anchors but an easy walk off.
